front.title: DMARC (Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting, and Conformance) Extension For TLDs (Top Level Domains)

abstract.t: DMARC (Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting, and Conformance) is a scalable mechanism by which a mail-originating organization can express domain-level policies and preferences for message validation, disposition, and reporting, that a mail-receiving organization can use to improve mail handling. DMARC itself does not apply to TLDs (Top Level Domains). For the subset of TLDs that require DMARC usage, it is appropriate to provide TLD level DMARC capability. This memo describes an extension to DMARC to enable a subset of DMARC functionality for such TLDs.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: DMARC provides email sending organizational policy information to email receivers. Due to the design of DMARC and the nature of the Internet email architecture, there are interoperability issues associated with DMARC deployment. These are discused in Interoperability Issues between DMARC and Indirect Email Flows. These issues are not applicable to TLDs, since they do not send mail.

DMARC, by design, does not support requirements of TLD operators. For TLDs that require use of DMARC, a subset of DMARC reporting and enforcement capability is needed for TLD operators to effectively manage and monitor implementation of TLD requirements.

Additionally, the ability to extend DMARC policy to operate against non-existent domains would enhance its utility for TLD Operators as well as Domain Owners. Originally, DMARC included this functionality, but it was removed after significant operational issues were discovered. This memo adds a new DMARC record tag to provide this capability on an optional, opt-in basis.

section.title: Terminology and Definitions
section.t: This section defines terms used in the rest of the document.

section.title: Conventions Used in This Document
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in BCP 14 when, and only when, they appear in all capitals, as shown here.

section.title: Top Level Domain (TLD)
section.t: The global Internet Domain Name System (DNS) is documented in numerous Requests for Comment (RFC). It defines a tree of names starting with root, ".", immediately below which are Top Level Domain names such as ".com" and ".us".

section.title: TLD Operator (TLDO)
section.t: A TLD Operator manages operations within their TLD based on guidance and rules from ICANN (Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers).

section.title: TLDO Controlled Domain Names
section.t: TLDO Controlled Domain Names are names in the DNS that are managed by TLDOs and not available for use as organizational domains (the term organizational domains is defined in DMARC). Depending on TLD policy, these will have one (e.g. ".com") or more (e.g. ".co.uk") or more name components.

section.title: Non-existent Domains
section.t: For DMARC purposes, a non-existent domain is a domain name that publishes none of A, AAAA, or MX records. This is a broader definition than that in NXDOMAIN.

section.title: TLD DMARC Updates to DMARC Requirements
section.t: This document updates DMARC as follows:

section.title: General Updates
section.t: References to "Domain Owners" also apply to TLDOs.

section.title: Section 6.1 DMARC Policy Record
section.t: TLD DMARC records are published as a subdomain of the TLD. For the TLD ".example", the TLDO would post DMARC preferences in a TXT record at "_dmarc.example".

section.title: Section 6.3. General Record Format
section.t: The rf and ruf tags are not applicable to TLD DMARC and MUST be ignored for TLD records.

section.title: Section 6.5. Domain Owner Actions
section.t: In addition to the DMARC domain owner actions, TLDOs will need to update the "DMARC TLD Registry". See IANA Considerations below.

section.title: Section 6.6.3. Policy Discovery
section.t: A new step between step 3 and 4 is added:

list.t: If the set is now empty and the TLD of the Organizational Domain is listed in the DMARC TLD Registry, the Mail Receiver MUST query the DNS for a DMARC TXT record at the DNS domain matching the TLD in place of the RFC5322.From domain in the message (if different). This record can contain policy to be asserted for subdomains of the TLD. A possibly empty set of records is returned.

section.title: 7.2. Aggregate Reports
section.t: NOTE: We would like to modify this section to allow multiple nxdomain subdomain reports to be reported in a single report. This would also require changes in the Appendix C XML schema. Recommend defering this to discussion in the IETF DMARC working group where the authors of the original design that disallows this can weigh in.

section.title: 7.3. Failure Reports
section.t: This section is not applicable to records identified via policy discovery step 3A.

section.title: Section 6.3. General Record Format
section.t: A new "np" tag is added:

list.t: Requested Mail Receiver policy for all non-existent domains (plain-text; OPTIONAL). Indicates the policy to be enacted by the Receiver at the request of the Domain Owner. It applies only to subdomains of the domain queried and not to the domain itself. Its syntax is identical to that of the "p" tag defined above. If absent, DMARC policy MUST NOT be applied for non-existent domains.

section.title: Privacy Considerations
section.t: This document does not change significantly change the Privacy Considerations of . Privacy considerations related to Failure Reports do not apply to TLD DMARC.

section.t: This document does not change the Security Considerations of .

section.title: IANA Considerations
section.t: This section describes actions requested to be completed by IANA.

section.title: DMARC Tag Registry Update
section.t: IANA is requested to add the following item to the registry:

texttable.c: Requested handling policy for non-existent domains

section.title: DMARC Top Level Domain (TLD) Registry
section.t: IANA is requested to create a new DMARC Top Level Domain (TLD) Registry within the Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting, and Conformance (DMARC) Parameters Registry.

Names of TLDs participating in TLD DMARC must be registered with IANA in this new sub-registry. New entries are assigned only for TLDs that require use of DMARC. The requirement has to be documented in a manner that satisfies the terms of Expert Review, per . The Designated Expert needs to confirm that provided documentation adequately describes TLD policy to require domain owners to use DMARC.
